    7402             : #if DEBUG
    7403             :     if (debug_level >= 5) {
    7404             :       db_virtual_function_override(ovfp);
    7405             :     }  /* if */
    7406             : #endif /* DEBUG */
    7407             :     if (ovfp->base_class == NULL) {
    7408             :       /* The overriding function is in the derived class, which is only
    7409             :          possible if this function is called for a late base class addition
    7410             :          (which happens in C++/CLI mode); in such cases, the scope for the
    7411             :          class definition must have been pushed. */
    7412             :       check_assertion(cli_or_cx_enabled &&
    7413             :                       class_type_supp(class_state->class_type)->assoc_scope
    7414             :                                                                      != NULL);
    7415             :     } else if (ovfp->base_class != base_class) {
    7416             :       a_base_class_ptr  bcp = base_classes_of(class_state->class_type);
    7417             :       for (; bcp != NULL; bcp = bcp->next) {
    7418             :         if (bcp == ovfp->base_class) break;
    7419             :       }  /* for */
    7420             :       check_assertion(bcp != NULL);
    7421             :     }  /* if */
    7422             :   }  /* for */
    7423             :   db_exit();
    7424             : }  /* verify_virt_func_override_list */
    7425             : 
    7426             : #endif /* EXPENSIVE_CHECKING */
    7427             : 
    7428        1296 : a_boolean congruent_paths(a_derivation_step_ptr  dsp1,
    7429             :                           a_derivation_step_ptr  dsp2)
    7430             : /*
    7431             : Return TRUE if the class sequence signatures of the paths headed by dsp1 and
    7432             : dsp2 are identical.
    7433             : */
    7434             : {
    7435        1296 :   a_boolean              congruent;
    7436        1296 :   a_derivation_step_ptr  dsp1_next, dsp2_next;
    7437             : 
    7438        1296 :   db_enter(4, "congruent_paths");
    7439             : #if DEBUG
    7440        1296 :   if (debug_level >= 4) {
    7441           0 :     fputs("comparing ", f_debug);
    7442           0 :     db_path(dsp1, /*show_offset=*/FALSE);
    7443           0 :     fputs(" and ", f_debug);
    7444           0 :     db_path(dsp2, /*show_offset=*/FALSE);
    7445             :   }  /* if */
    7446             : #endif /* DEBUG */
    7447        1296 :   congruent = FALSE;
    7448             :   /* Only the start of a derivation and the end of a derivation can be
    7449             :      virtual.  Check the start. */
    7450        1296 :   if (dsp1->base_class->is_virtual == dsp2->base_class->is_virtual) {
    7451        2592 :     for (;;) {
    7452             :       /* Check the types of the corresponding steps. */
    7453        2592 :       if (!same_entities(dsp1->base_class->type, dsp2->base_class->type)) {
    7454             :         break;
    7455             :       }  /* if */
    7456             :       /* Advance to the next step. */
    7457        2592 :       dsp1_next = dsp1->next;
    7458        2592 :       dsp2_next = dsp2->next;
    7459        2592 :       if (dsp1_next == NULL) {
    7460             :         /* At the end of path1.  Terminate the loop after one more check. */
    7461        1296 :         if (dsp2_next == NULL) {
    7462             :           /* At the end of path2 also.  Again, check the end of the derivation
    7463             :              for matching is_virtual flags. */
    7464        1296 :           if (dsp1->base_class->is_virtual == dsp2->base_class->is_virtual) {
    7465        1296 :             congruent = TRUE;
    7466             :           }  /* if */
    7467             :         }  /* if */
    7468             :         break;
    7469        1296 :       } else if (dsp2_next == NULL) {
    7470             :         /* At the end of path2.  Terminate the loop. */
    7471             :         break;
    7472             :       }  /* if */
    7473             :       /* Both paths have additional steps, so keep checking. */
    7474             :       dsp1 = dsp1_next;
    7475             :       dsp2 = dsp2_next;
    7476             :     }  /* for */
    7477             :   }  /* if */
    7478             : #if DEBUG
    7479        1296 :   if (debug_level >= 4) {
    7480           0 :     fprintf(f_debug, " : %scongruent\n", congruent ? "" : "not ");
    7481             :   }  /* if */
    7482             : #endif /* DEBUG */
    7483        1296 :   db_exit();
    7484        1296 :   return congruent;
    7485             : }  /* congruent_paths */
    7486             : 
    7487             : 
    7488         959 : static a_derivation_step_ptr copy_and_extend_path(a_derivation_step_ptr path,
    7489             :                                                   a_derivation_step_ptr step)
    7490             : /*
    7491             : Given a derivation path "path", make a copy of it and extend by another step
    7492             : represented by "step".  Return a pointer to the new path.  When path is
    7493             : NULL, a pointer to step is returned.
    7494             : */
    7495             : {
    7496         959 :   a_derivation_step_ptr  dsp, new_dsp;
    7497         959 :   a_derivation_step_ptr  new_path = NULL, end_of_new_path = NULL;
    7498             : 
    7499         959 :   if (path == NULL) {
    7500             :     new_path = step;
    7501             :   } else {
    7502        2350 :     for (dsp = path; dsp != NULL; dsp = dsp->next) {
    7503        1391 :       new_dsp = make_derivation_step(dsp->base_class,
    7504             :                                      (a_derivation_step_ptr)NULL);
    7505        1391 :       if (new_path == NULL) {
    7506             :         new_path = new_dsp;
    7507             :       } else {
    7508         432 :         end_of_new_path->next = new_dsp;
    7509             :       }  /* if */
    7510        1391 :       end_of_new_path = new_dsp;
    7511             :     }  /* if */
    7512         959 :     end_of_new_path->next = step;
    7513             :   }  /* if */
    7514         959 :   return new_path;
    7515             : }  /* copy_and_extend_path */
    7516             : 
    7517             : #if !IA64_ABI
    7518             : 
    7519             : static void set_pointer_base_class(a_base_class_ptr       base_class,
    7520             :                                    a_derivation_step_ptr  path)
    7521             : /*
    7522             : Base class is a virtual base class for which the pointer_base_class field has
    7523             : not yet been set.  Set it to point to the nonvirtual base class in its
    7524             : derivation path that is furthest along the derivation path without having any
    7525             : virtual base classes of its own.  For instance, given this derivation:
    7526             :     ==>D==>C==>V1==>B==>A==>V2
    7527             : (where base classes V1 and V2 are virtual and the others are nonvirtual)
    7528             : the pointer_base_class for both V1 and V2 is C.
    7529             : */
    7530             : {
    7531             :   a_derivation_step_ptr     dsp;
    7532             :   a_base_class_ptr          bcp, pointer_base_class;
    7533             :   a_base_class_derivation_ptr  bcdp;
    7534             : 
    7535             :   /* Find the segment of the derivation path that is headed by a direct base
    7536             :      class.  In the example above, the path for V2 is ==>V1==>B==>A==>V2,
    7537             :      but V1 is not a direct base class; therefore, we look at V1's path,
    7538             :      namely, ==>D==>C==>V1, and find that D is a direct base class. */
    7539             :   dsp = path;
    7540             :   if (path->base_class->is_virtual) {
    7541             :     pointer_base_class = path->base_class->pointer_base_class;
    7542             :   } else {
    7543             :     /* If the head of the derivation is non-virtual, we may have a candidate
    7544             :        for a pointer base class. */
    7545             :     check_assertion(dsp->next != NULL);
    7546             :     /* Look for the second-to-last base class in this path segment.  (The
    7547             :        last path entry should be either base_class itself. */
    7548             :     while (dsp->next->next != NULL) dsp = dsp->next;
    7549             :     pointer_base_class = dsp->base_class;
    7550             :   }  /* if */
    7551             :   if (pointer_base_class != NULL) {
    7552             :     bcp = corresponding_base_class(base_class, pointer_base_class->type,
    7553             :                                    (a_base_class_ptr)NULL);
    7554             :     if (bcp->pointer_base_class != NULL) {
    7555             :       /* Its pointer is embedded in some other base class, so we don't want it
    7556             :          after all.  In such a case we'll encounter that base class later in
    7557             :          processing and use it then. */
    7558             :     } else {
    7559             :       base_class->pointer_base_class = pointer_base_class;
    7560             :       if (base_class->type->
    7561             :             variant.class_struct_union.any_virtual_base_classes) {
    7562             :         for (bcp = base_classes_of(base_class->derived_class);
    7563             :              bcp != NULL;
    7564             :              bcp = bcp->next) {
    7565             :           if (bcp->is_virtual && bcp->pointer_base_class == NULL) {
    7566             :             for (bcdp = bcp->derivation; bcdp != NULL; bcdp = bcdp->next) {
    7567             :               if (bcdp->path->base_class == base_class) {
    7568             :                 set_pointer_base_class(bcp, bcdp->path);
    7569             :                 break;
    7570             :               }  /* if */
    7571             :             }  /* for */
    7572             :           }  /* if */
    7573             :         }  /* for */
    7574             :       }  /* if */
    7575             :     }  /* if */
    7576             :   }  /* if */
    7577             : }  /* set_pointer_base_class */
    7578             : 
    7579             : #endif /* !IA64_ABI */
    7580             : 
    7581             : #if CFRONT_OBJECT_CODE_COMPATIBILITY
    7582             : 
    7583             : static void set_data_section_base_class(a_base_class_ptr       base_class,
    7584             :                                         a_derivation_step_ptr  path)
    7585             : /*
    7586             : In cfront-compatibility mode the data section for a virtual base class
    7587             : may be embedded in the data section of some other base class.  When this
    7588             : is the case, the data_section_base_class field in the entry for the virtual
    7589             : base class will contain a pointer to the base class that contains its data
    7590             : section.  (This is not an issue in normal layout mode since virtual base
    7591             : class data sections are never embedded.)  Here are some examples that
    7592             : reveal how cfront decides when a virtual base class is embedded and when
    7593             : it is not:
    7594             : 
    7595             : (1) Virtual base class data sections are not embedded in incomplete
    7596             :     subobjects -- i.e., in the first direct nonvirtual base class:
    7597             : 
    7598             :   class A { int a; };                       //     A
    7599             :   class B : public virtual A { int b; };    //     |
    7600             :   class C : public B { int c; };            //     B
    7601             :                                             //     |
    7602             : Cfront's layout:                            //     C
    7603             : 
    7604             :   struct A {
    7605             :     int a__1A ;
    7606             :   };
    7607             :   struct B {
    7608             :     int b__1B ;
    7609             :     struct A *PA;
    7610             :     struct A OA;
    7611             :   };
    7612             :   struct C {
    7613             :     int b__1B ;
    7614             :     struct A *PA;
    7615             :     int c__1C ;
    7616             :     struct A OA;
    7617             :   };
    7618             : 
    7619             : Here, the data section for virtual base class A is allocated independently
    7620             : in C and not embedded in B, since be is not a complete subobject of C.
    7621             : 
    7622             : (2) Virtual base class data sections are (usually) embedded in complete
    7623             :     subobjects.
    7624             : 
    7625             :   class A { };                             //  A
    7626             :   class B : public virtual A { };          //   \
    7627             :   class C { };                             //    B   C
    7628             :   class D : public C, public B { };        //     \ /
    7629             :                                            //      D
    7630             : Cfront's layout:
    7631             : 
    7632             :   struct A {
    7633             :     int a__1A ;
    7634             :   };
    7635             :   struct B {
    7636             :     int b__1B ;
    7637             :     struct A *PA;
    7638             :     struct A OA;
    7639             :   };
    7640             :   struct C {
    7641             :     int c__1C ;
    7642             :   };
    7643             :   struct D {
    7644             :     int c__1C ;
    7645             :     struct B OB;
    7646             :     int d__1D ;
    7647             :   };
    7648             : 
    7649             : In this case the data section for virtual base class A is not allocated
    7650             : independently in D.  Rather, the A embedded in B is used, since B is a
    7651             : complete subobject of D.
    7652             : 
    7653             : (3) When a virtual base class appears more than once in a class, the
    7654             :     data section is (usually) that of the first complete subobject it
    7655             :     belongs to.
    7656             : 
    7657             :   class A { int a; };                       //      A
    7658             :   class B : public virtual A { int b; };    //     /|\
    7659             :   class C : public virtual A { int c; };    //    B | C
    7660             :   class D : public C, public B,             //     \|/
    7661             :             public virtual A { int d; };    //      D   
    7662             : 
    7663             : Cfront's layout:
    7664             : 
    7665             :   struct A {
    7666             :     int a__1A ;
    7667             :   };
    7668             :   struct B {
    7669             :     int b__1B ;
    7670             :     struct A *PA;
    7671             :     struct A OA;
    7672             :   };
    7673             :   struct C {
    7674             :     int c__1C ;
    7675             :     struct A *PA;
    7676             :     struct A OA;
    7677             :   };
    7678             :   struct D {
    7679             :     int b__1B ;
    7680             :     struct A *PA;
    7681             :     struct C OC;
    7682             :     int d__1D ;
    7683             :   };
    7684             : 
    7685             : Here the data section for virtual base A in D is embedded in C, because
    7686             : B is not complete and even though A is also a direct base class of D.
    7687             : 
    7688             : (4) An "interesting" anomaly (or bug?) appears when another level of
    7689             :     inheritance is added to example (3):
    7690             : 
    7691             :   class A { int a; };                       //      A   
    7692             :   class B : public virtual A { int b; };    //     /|\
    7693             :   class C : public virtual A { int c; };    //    B | C 
    7694             :   class D : public B, public C,             //     \|/  
    7695             :             public virtual A { int d; };    //      D   
    7696             :   class E : public D { int e; };            //      |
    7697             :                                             //      E
    7698             : Cfront's layout:
    7699             : 
    7700             :   struct A {
    7701             :     int a__1A ;
    7702             :   };
    7703             :   struct B {
    7704             :     int b__1B ;
    7705             :     struct A *PA;
    7706             :     struct A OA;
    7707             :   };
    7708             :   struct C {
    7709             :     int c__1C ;
    7710             :     struct A *PA;
    7711             :     struct A OA;
    7712             :   };
    7713             :   struct D {
    7714             :     int b__1B ;
    7715             :     struct A *PA;
    7716             :     struct C OC;
    7717             :     int d__1D ;
    7718             :   };
    7719             :   struct E {
    7720             :     int b__1B ;
    7721             :     struct A *PA;
    7722             :     struct C OC;
    7723             :     int d__1D ;
    7724             :     int e__1E ;
    7725             :     struct A OA;
    7726             :   };
    7727             : 
    7728             : What's anomalous about this case is that, even though there is a copy of
    7729             : A's data section in C, and even though C is a complete subobject of E,
    7730             : another copy of A's data section is allocated in E.
    7731             : 
    7732             : The rule here seems to be that a virtual base class (e.g., A) that is an
    7733             : indirect base class of an incomplete subobject base class (e.g., D) is
    7734             : treated as though it were not embedded in an intermediate complete
    7735             : subobject (e.g., C).
    7736             : */
    7737             : {
    7738             :   a_derivation_step_ptr  dsp = path;
    7739             :   a_base_class_ptr       bcp;
    7740             : 
    7741             :   db_enter(4, "set_data_section_base_class");
    7742             :   /* If the first entry on the derivation path is a complete subobject,
    7743             :      it may have virtual base classes embedded within it. */
    7744             :   if (dsp->base_class->complete_subobject) {
    7745             :     if (dsp->base_class->is_virtual &&
    7746             :         dsp->base_class->data_section_base_class == NULL) {
    7747             :       if (base_class->data_section_base_class == NULL &&
    7748             :           !dsp->base_class->direct) {
    7749             :         /* dsp refers to a virtual base class which is not itself embedded.
    7750             :            Only mark base_class as embedded within dsp->base_class (and then
    7751             :            only provisionally) if this is a direct derivation. */
    7752             :         if (dsp->next->base_class == base_class) {
    7753             :           /* It is a direct derivation.  See if the base class that corresponds
    7754             :              to base_class is embedded in the context of dsp->base_class->type.
    7755             :              If so, defer the designation. */
    7756             :           bcp = corresponding_base_class(base_class, dsp->base_class->type,
    7757             :                                          (a_base_class_ptr)NULL);
    7758             :           if (bcp->data_section_base_class == NULL) {
    7759             :             base_class->data_section_base_class = dsp->base_class;
    7760             :           }  /* if */
    7761             :         }  /* if */
    7762             :       }  /* if */
    7763             :     } else {
    7764             :       /* Traverse the path. */
    7765             :       for (;; dsp = dsp->next) {
    7766             :         if (dsp->next->base_class == base_class ||
    7767             :             !dsp->next->base_class->complete_subobject) {
    7768             :           /* dsp represents an intermediate base class.  If the next entry
    7769             :              on the path is NULL (i.e., if dsp is the last entry before the
    7770             :              base_class) or is an incomplete subobject (meaning it cannot
    7771             :              have data sections for virtual base classes embedded within it),
    7772             :              then this is where base_class may be embedded. */
    7773             :           bcp = corresponding_base_class(base_class, dsp->base_class->type,
    7774             :                                          (a_base_class_ptr)NULL);
    7775             :           if (bcp->data_section_base_class == NULL) {
    7776             :             base_class->data_section_base_class = dsp->base_class;
    7777             :           }  /* if */
    7778             :           break;
    7779             :         }  /* if */
    7780             :       }  /* for */
    7781             :     }  /* if */
    7782             :   }  /* if */
    7783             :   db_exit();
    7784             : }  /* set_data_section_base_class */
    7785             : 
    7786             : #endif /* CFRONT_OBJECT_CODE_COMPATIBILITY */
    7787             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    7788             : 
    7789             : static void set_preferred_derivation_for_managed_base(a_base_class_ptr  bcp)
    7790             : /*
    7791             : In managed classes all derivations are public.  It therefore doesn't matter
    7792             : much which derivation is considered "preferred", except that in the case of
    7793             : System::Object the derivation via a ref class should be preferred since
    7794             : derivations via an interface class are not always considered during lookups.
    7795             : On the other hand, a preferred derivation must be picked early because managed
    7796             : bases are sometimes added late (i.e., after the derived class scope has been
    7797             : pushed) and so lookup for another late-added base may expect a preferred path
    7798             : to have been picked.
    7799             : bcp is a managed base class being added.
    7800             : */
    7801             : {
    7802             :   
    7803             :   a_base_class_derivation_ptr  bcdp = bcp->derivation;
    7804             : 
    7805             :   check_assertion(bcdp != NULL);
    7806             :   /* Pick the first added derivation as the "preferred" one or a direct
    7807             :      derivation if one exists.  In the case of System::Object, pick a
    7808             :      derivation not involving an interface class if one exists. */
    7809             :   if (bcdp->next == NULL) {
    7810             :     /* There is only one derivation, so it is preferred. */
    7811             :     bcdp->preferred = TRUE;
    7812             :   } else if (bcp->direct) {
    7813             :     for (; bcdp != NULL; bcdp = bcdp->next) {
    7814             :       bcdp->preferred = bcdp->direct;
    7815             :     }  /* if */
    7816             :   } else if (!is_immediate_cli_interface_type(bcp->type)) {
    7817             :     /* System::Object. */
    7818             :     for (; bcdp != NULL; bcdp = bcdp->next) {
    7819             :       a_derivation_step_ptr  step = bcdp->path;
    7820             :       bcdp->preferred = TRUE;
    7821             :       /* If this derivation involves an interface class mark it as not
    7822             :          preferred. */
    7823             :       for (; step != NULL; step = step->next) {
    7824             :         if (is_immediate_cli_interface_type(step->base_class->type)) {
    7825             :           bcdp->preferred = FALSE;
    7826             :           break;
    7827             :         }  /* if */
    7828             :       }  /* for */
    7829             :       if (bcdp->preferred) break;
    7830             :     }  /* for */
    7831             :     /* If all the derivations involved an interface class, mark the first one
    7832             :        (arbitrarily) as preferred.  Otherwise, ensure the remaining derivations
    7833             :        are not marked as preferred. */
    7834             :     if (bcdp == NULL) {
    7835             :       bcp->derivation->preferred = TRUE;
    7836             :     } else {
    7837             :       for (bcdp = bcdp->next; bcdp != NULL; bcdp = bcdp->next) {
    7838             :         bcdp->preferred = FALSE;
    7839             :       }  /* for */
    7840             :     }  /* if */
    7841             :   }  /* if */

    7844             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    7845             : 
    7846        6684 : static a_derivation_step_ptr update_base_class_derivation(
    7847             :                                          a_base_class_ptr       base_class,
    7848             :                                          a_derivation_step_ptr  path,
    7849             :                                          an_access_specifier    access)
    7850             : /*
    7851             : base_class is a direct base class declared explicitly (in which case path is
    7852             : NULL) or an indirect base class implied by the declaration of a direct base
    7853             : class (in which case path is non-NULL).  access is the access to be applied
    7854             : for this derivation, which for indirect base classes corresponds to the access
    7855             : of the last step on the path.  This routine allocates a base-class-derivation
    7856             : entry for the derivation and supplies it with the appropriate derivation
    7857             : path and access.
    7858             : */
    7859             : {
    7860        6684 :   a_base_class_derivation_ptr  bcdp, new_bcdp;
    7861        6684 :   a_derivation_step_ptr        step;
    7862             : 
    7863             :   /* Allocate the entry and make a step entry. */
    7864        6684 :   new_bcdp = alloc_base_class_derivation();
    7865        6684 :   step = make_derivation_step(base_class, (a_derivation_step_ptr)NULL);
    7866        6684 :   if (path == NULL) {
    7867             :     /* A direct base class. */
    7868        5725 :     new_bcdp->direct = TRUE;
    7869        5725 :     new_bcdp->path = step;
    7870             :   } else {
    7871             :     /* An indirect base class. */
    7872         959 :     new_bcdp->path = copy_and_extend_path(path, step);
    7873             :   }  /* if */
    7874        6684 :   new_bcdp->access = access;
    7875        6684 :   if (!base_class->is_virtual) {
    7876             :     /* In the case of a nonvirtual base class, there is only one derivation,
    7877             :        so it is marked as "preferred" by default. */
    7878        6604 :     new_bcdp->preferred = TRUE;
    7879        6604 :     base_class->derivation = new_bcdp;
    7880        6604 :     path = new_bcdp->path;
    7881             :   } else {
    7882             :     /* For virtual base classes, this may be one derivation among several.
    7883             :        Add it to the end of the linked list of base-class-derivation
    7884             :        entries. */
    7885          80 :     bcdp = base_class->derivation;
    7886          80 :     if (bcdp == NULL) {
    7887          64 :       base_class->derivation = new_bcdp;
    7888             :     } else {
    7889          16 :       while (bcdp->next != NULL) bcdp = bcdp->next;
    7890          16 :       bcdp->next = new_bcdp;
    7891             :     }  /* if */
    7892             :     /* Note that the preferred flag is set later. */
    7893             : #if !IA64_ABI
    7894             :     /* Set the pointer-base-class (the nonvirtual base class in which a
    7895             :        pointer to this virtual base class may be found) if appropriate. */
    7896             :     if (path != NULL) {
    7897             :       if (base_class->pointer_base_class == NULL) {
    7898             :         set_pointer_base_class(base_class, new_bcdp->path);
    7899             :       }  /* if */
    7900             : #if CFRONT_OBJECT_CODE_COMPATIBILITY
    7901             :       /* In cfront mode set the data section base class, which is where the
    7902             :          data section of this virtual base class may be embedded. */
    7903             :       if (base_class->data_section_base_class == NULL ||
    7904             :           base_class->data_section_base_class->is_virtual) {
    7905             :         set_data_section_base_class(base_class, new_bcdp->path);
    7906             :       }  /* if */
    7907             : #endif /* CFRONT_OBJECT_CODE_COMPATIBILITY */
    7908             :     }  /* if */
    7909             : #endif /* !IA64_ABI */
    7910             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    7911             :     if (is_immediate_managed_class_type(base_class->type)) {
    7912             :       /* The preferred derivation path for C++/CLI managed class types must
    7913             :          be set early. */
    7914             :       set_preferred_derivation_for_managed_base(base_class);
    7915             :     }  /* if */
    7916             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    7917             :     /* Return a different path than the one stored in the base-class-
    7918             :        derivation entry.  This is because each virtual base class is the
    7919             :        start of a new segment. */
    7920             :     path = step;
    7921             :   }  /* if */
    7922        6684 :   return path;
    7923             : }  /* update_base_class_derivation */
    7924             : 
    7925             : 
    7926       18602 : static void set_shares_virtual_function_info_flag(a_type_ptr       class_type,
    7927             :                                                   a_base_class_ptr base_class)
    7928             : /*

    8072             : 
    8073             : static void add_indirect_base_class(a_base_class_ptr      base_class_to_copy,
    8074             :                                     a_base_class_ptr      directly_derived_bcp,
    8075             :                                     a_derivation_step_ptr path,
    8076             :                                     a_base_class_ptr      *p_end_of_add_list,
    8077             :                                     a_type_ptr            new_class)
    8078             : /*
    8079             : 
    8080             : Create a new indirect base class based on base_class_to_copy and,
    8081             : typically, add it to the end of the base classes list for new_class.
    8082             : directly_derived_bcp points to a recently created (or copied) base class,
    8083             : a direct or indirect base class of new_class, of which the new base class
    8084             : will be a direct base class. In addition, check for ambiguity and
    8085             : duplicate paths.  The copy will be a base class of new_class.
    8086             : 
    8087             : */
    8088             : {
    8089             :   a_base_class_ptr     new_bcp = NULL, bcp;

    8092             : 
    8093             :   db_enter(3, "add_indirect_base_class");
    8094             :   /* Record the derivation path from the most derived class to the class that
    8095             :      is directly derived from the new base class; it will be copied and
    8096             :      extended to produce the new base class's derivation. */
    8097             :   /* We will mark the derivation's access by copying the access associated
    8098             :      with the first derivation of base_class_to_copy, which should also be a
    8099             :      direct derivation. */

    8107             :            base class referring to the same class type is already on the base

    8154             :   for (bcp = base_classes_of(new_class); bcp != NULL; bcp = bcp->next) {

    8166             :   for (bcp = base_classes_of(new_bcp->type); bcp != NULL; bcp = bcp->next) {

    8168             :       continue;

    8170             :       /* A virtual base class is marked as "direct" if any of its paths
    8171             :          is direct.  However, for our purposes, the "first" path (first in
    8172             :          a depth-first left-to-right traversal of the derivation graph)
    8173             :          must be direct. */

    8175             :         any_direct_virtual_base_class_fixup = TRUE;
    8176             :         continue;

    8184             :   } else {
    8185             :     (*p_end_of_add_list)->next = new_bcp;
    8186             :   }  /* if */
    8187             :   *p_end_of_add_list = new_bcp;
    8188             :   /* Set shares_virtual_function_info for a base class of new_bcp, if
    8189             :      appropriate. */
    8190             :   set_shares_virtual_function_info_flag(new_class, new_bcp);
    8191             :   /* Do path fixup, if necessary. */
    8192             :   if (any_direct_virtual_base_class_fixup) {
    8193             :     a_base_class_ptr             fixup_bcp;
    8194             :     a_base_class_derivation_ptr  bcdp;
    8195             : 
    8196             :     for (bcp = base_classes_of(new_bcp->type); bcp != NULL; bcp = bcp->next) {
    8197             :       if (bcp->direct && bcp->is_virtual) {
    8198             :         bcdp = bcp->derivation;
    8199             :         if (!bcdp->direct) {
    8200             :           /* Add path information about a direct virtual base class of
    8201             :              new_direct_bcp that was not first in the depth-first
    8202             :              left-to-right traversal of the latter's derivation graph. */
    8203             :           /* Find the base class in new_class that corresponds to bcp. */
    8204             :           fixup_bcp = corresp_base_class(bcp, new_bcp);
    8205             :           /* Find the derivation, which has the appropriate access. */
    8206             :           do {
    8207             :             bcdp = bcdp->next;
    8208             :           } while (!bcdp->direct);
    8209             :           /* Update the path list. */
    8210             :           (void)update_base_class_derivation(fixup_bcp, path, bcdp->access);
    8211             :         }  /* if */
    8212             :       }  /* if */
    8213             :     }  /* for */
    8214             :   }  /* if */
    8215             :   /* Branch here for duplicate virtual base class. */
    8216             : done:;
    8217             :   db_exit();
    8218             : }  /* add_indirect_base_class */
    8219             : 
    8220             : 
    8221          64 : static void set_preferred_base_class_derivation(a_type_ptr        class_type,
    8222             :                                                 a_base_class_ptr  base_class)
    8223             : /*
    8224             : When a class is derived from a virtual base class by more than one
    8225             : derivation path, only one instance of the virtual base class will actually
    8226             : show up in the base class graph.  For instance, if V is a virtually base
    8227             : class of A and B, the base class graphs for A and B will be identical:
    8228             :                 X   Y     X   Y
    8229             :                  \ /       \ /
    8230             :                   V         V
    8231             :                   |         |
    8232             :                   A         B
    8233             : but when they are both declared as base classes of C, the resulting graph
    8234             : looks like this:
    8235             :                      X   Y
    8236             :                       \ /
    8237             :                        V
    8238             :                       / \
    8239             :                      A   B
    8240             :                       \ /
    8241             :                        C
    8242             : The derivations for X and Y in C are represented as ==>V==>X and ==>V==>Y,
    8243             : respectively, but V in C has two derivations, ==>A==>V and ==>B==>V.  Both
    8244             : paths are represented in the IL -- the base class entry for V points to a
    8245             : linked list of virtual-derivation entries, each of which points to a
    8246             : derivation of V.
    8247             : 
    8248             : This routine is called to identify the "preferred" path -- the sequence of
    8249             : casts that affords the greatest "normal" accessibility (i.e., without
    8250             : special treatment for casts in the context of member or friend functions).
    8251             : When there are two entries with equally good access, a direct base class is
    8252             : preferred over an indirect one, and an indirect base class with no virtual
    8253             : base classes in its derivation is preferred over one that has virtual base
    8254             : classes in its derivation.
    8255             : 
    8256             : Note that the virtual base class appears on the base class list in the
    8257             : position of its first appearance in the depth-first left-to-right traversal
    8258             : of the base specifiers graph.  This position is independent of the which
    8259             : appearance of the base class happens to have been marked preferred.
    8260             : */
    8261             : {
    8262          64 :   a_base_class_derivation_ptr
    8263          64 :                        bcdp, preferred_bcdp = NULL;
    8264          64 :   an_access_specifier  access,
    8265          64 :                        preferred_access = (an_access_specifier)as_inaccessible;
    8266             : 
    8267          64 :   db_enter(4, "set_preferred_base_class_derivation");
    8268             :   /* Has this set of base class derivations been checked yet?  This can be
    8269             :      determined by seeing if any has the preferred flag set already. */
    8270         144 :   for (bcdp = base_class->derivation; bcdp != NULL; bcdp = bcdp->next) {
    8271             :     /* Preferred flag has already been set for this group of derivations. */
    8272          80 :     if (bcdp->preferred) goto done;
    8273             :   }  /* for */
    8274             :   /* Traverse the linked list of base class derivations. */
    8275         144 :   for (bcdp = base_class->derivation; bcdp != NULL; bcdp = bcdp->next) {
    8276          80 :     if (bcdp->path->base_class->is_virtual &&
    8277             :         bcdp->path->base_class != base_class) {
    8278             :       /* If this virtual base class has a virtual base class in its
    8279             :          derivation path, the intermediate step has to be processed first. */
    8280           0 :       set_preferred_base_class_derivation(class_type, bcdp->path->base_class);
    8281             :     }  /* if */
    8282             :     /* Determine the accessibility of a public member of the virtual base
    8283             :        class in the context of the most derived class. */
    8284          80 :     access = access_to_end_of_path((an_access_specifier)as_public,
    8285             :                                    bcdp->path, bcdp);
    8286          80 :     if (bcdp == base_class->derivation) {
    8287             :       /* Prefer the first unless another turns out to have better access. */
    8288             :       preferred_bcdp = bcdp;
    8289             :       preferred_access = access;
    8290             :     } else {
    8291             :       /* Compare the two paths. */
    8292          16 :       if (is_more_accessible(access, preferred_access)) {
    8293             :         /* The new one is more accessible.  Use it. */
    8294             :         preferred_bcdp = bcdp;
    8295             :         preferred_access = access;
    8296          16 :       } else if (access == preferred_access) {
    8297             :         /* No preference based on accessibility.  Look for other criteria. */
    8298          16 :         check_assertion(preferred_bcdp != NULL);
    8299          16 :         if (!preferred_bcdp->direct) {
    8300          16 :           if (bcdp->direct) {
    8301             :             /* Choose a direct base class over an indirect. */
    8302             :             preferred_bcdp = bcdp;
    8303          16 :           } else if (!bcdp->path->base_class->is_virtual &&
    8304          16 :                      preferred_bcdp->path->base_class->is_virtual) {
    8305             :             /* Both are indirect, but we choose a path with no virtual steps
    8306             :                over one that a path that has virtual steps. */
    8307           0 :             preferred_bcdp = bcdp;
    8308             :           }  /* if */
    8309             :         }  /* if */
    8310             :       }  /* if */
    8311             :     }  /* if */
    8312             :   }  /* for */
    8313             :   /* coverity[var_deref_op] */
    8314          64 :   preferred_bcdp->preferred = TRUE;
    8315          64 : done:;
    8316          64 :   db_exit();
    8317          64 : }  /* set_preferred_base_class_derivation */
    8318             : 
    8319             : 
    8320        5725 : static void mark_base_dependent_if_needed
    8321             :                                    (a_base_class_ptr              bcp, 
    8322             :                                     a_class_def_state_ptr         class_state,
    8323             :                                     a_base_class_sequence_number  proto_num)
    8324             : /*
    8325             : bcp represents a direct base class generated during a real instantiation of a
    8326             : class template (the instance is described by class_state) and proto_num is the
    8327             : sequence number of the corresponding base in the prototype instantiation.

    8330             : */

    8356        1825 :     if (proto_bcp != NULL) {
    8357             :       /* Normal case: We find the corresponding base of the prototype

    8359        1825 :       bcp->ignore_during_dependent_lookup =

    8361             :       /* Indicate that this class has a dependent base if this base class

    8376             : #if IA64_ABI
    8377             : 
    8378       12327 : static a_base_class_ptr *compute_preorder_base_classes(
    8379             :                                                 a_type_ptr        type_ptr,
    8380             :                                                 a_base_class_ptr  base,
    8381             :                                                 a_base_class_ptr  *end_of_list)
    8382             : /*
    8383             : Compute the preorder base class list for type_ptr.  base is the base of
    8384             : type_ptr whose bases should be added to the list, or NULL if the direct bases
    8385             : of type_ptr should be added.  *end_of_list points to the end of the preorder
    8386             : list.  Returns a pointer to the new end of the list.
    8387             : */
    8388             : {
    8389       12327 :   a_base_class_ptr first_base, bcp, new_base, old_base;
    8390       12327 :   a_base_class_sequence_number next_base;
    8391             : 
    8392       12327 :   first_base = base_classes_of((base == NULL) ? type_ptr : base->type);
    8393             :   /* Skip to the end if this type has no base classes.  */
    8394       12327 :   if (first_base == NULL) goto done;
    8395             :   bcp = first_base;
    8396        6684 :   for (next_base = 1; ; next_base++) {
    8397             :     /* Care must be taken to traverse the direct base classes in declaration
    8398             :        order.  In particular, it is not sufficient to simply traverse the
    8399             :        base class list and act on the direct bases.  Consider the following
    8400             :        example:
    8401             :          struct V {};
    8402             :          struct B: virtual V {};
    8403             :          struct D: virtual B, virtual V {};
    8404             :        The base class list for D will first list the virtual base V because
    8405             :        it is the "leftmost" base class of B, but it is also marked "direct".
    8406             :        This for-loop therefore enumerates the direct base numbers which we
    8407             :        then search for using an additional loop.  In most cases, this will
    8408             :        only require a single traversal of the base class list, but in some
    8409             :        unusual hierarchies the cost of the nested loops could be quadratic
    8410             :        in the length of the base class list. */
    8411       13278 :     a_base_class_ptr start = bcp;
    8412             :     /* Look for the base with the next sequence number. */
    8413       16272 :     while (bcp->direct_base_number != next_base) {
    8414        9588 :       bcp = bcp->next;
    8415        9588 :       if (bcp == NULL) {
    8416        6594 :         bcp = first_base;
    8417             :       }  /* if */
    8418             :       /* If we get back to the place where we started, then there is no next
    8419             :          base.  */
    8420        9588 :       if (bcp == start) break;
    8421             :     }  /* while */
    8422             :     /* If there was no base with the next sequence number then we have reached
    8423             :        the end of the list.  */
    8424       13278 :     if (bcp->direct_base_number != next_base) break;
    8425             :     /* Find the base of type_ptr that corresponds to bcp. */
    8426        6684 :     if (base == NULL) {
    8427             :       new_base = bcp;
    8428             :     } else {
    8429         959 :       new_base = corresp_base_class(bcp, base);
    8430             :     } /* if */
    8431             :     /* If the new_base is virtual, we may already have a copy on the
    8432             :        list. */
    8433        6684 :     if (new_base->is_virtual) {
    8434          80 :       for (old_base = preorder_base_classes_of(type_ptr); 
    8435         112 :            old_base != NULL;
    8436          32 :            old_base = old_base->next_preorder) {
    8437          48 :         if (old_base == new_base) break;
    8438             :       }  /* for */
    8439             :       /* If the virtual base is already on the preorder list, skip this
    8440             :          base. */
    8441          80 :       if (old_base != NULL) continue;
    8442             :     }  /* if */
    8443             :     /* Add new_base to the list. */
    8444        6668 :     *end_of_list = new_base;
    8445        6668 :     end_of_list = &new_base->next_preorder;
    8446             :     /* Recursively add the base classes of new_base. */
    8447        6668 :     end_of_list = compute_preorder_base_classes(type_ptr, new_base,
    8448             :                                                 end_of_list);
    8449             :   }  /* for */
    8450        6594 : done:
    8451       12327 :   return end_of_list;
    8452             : }  /* compute_preorder_base_classes */
    8453             : 
    8454             : 
    8455          48 : static a_boolean is_nearly_empty_class(a_type_ptr type)
    8456             : /*
    8457             : Return TRUE if (and only if) the type (which must be a class, struct, or 
    8458             : union type) is "nearly empty", i.e, has no data except a virtual pointer,
    8459             : as defined in the IA64 ABI.
    8460             : */
    8461             : {
    8462          48 :   a_boolean                   nearly_empty = TRUE;
    8463          48 :   a_field_ptr                 fp;
    8464          48 :   a_base_class_ptr            bcp;
    8465          48 :   a_class_type_supplement_ptr ctsp;
    8466             :

    8468          48 :   ctsp = type->variant.class_struct_union.extra_info;
    8469             :   /* If there is no virtual function table, then the class is not nearly 
    8470             :      empty. */
    8471          48 :   if (!needs_virtual_function_table(type) &&
    8472          16 :       ctsp->virtual_function_info_base_class == NULL) {
    8473             :     nearly_empty = FALSE;
    8474             :   } else {
    8475             :     /* There must be no non-static data members other than zero-width
    8476             :        bitfields. */

    8567             : static void scan_inheritance_kind(a_type_ptr           type_ptr,
    8568             :                                   an_ms_attribute_ptr  *p_ms_attributes,
    8569             :                                   a_boolean            *is_virtual,
    8570             :                                   an_access_specifier  *access,
    8571             :                                   a_boolean            *explicit_access)
    8572             : /*
    8573             : Scan any of the keywords "virtual", "public", "private", and "protected"
    8574             : that might precede a base class specifier in the definition of the class
    8575             : represented by type_ptr.  Set *is_virtual to TRUE if "virtual" is seen,
    8576             : and set *access to any explicitly mentioned access specifier (if such an
    8577             : explicit specifier is seen, set *explicit_access to TRUE).  Issue any
    8578             : diagnostics that can be emitted based on this information.
    8579             : */
    8580             : {
    8581             :   a_boolean  access_already_specified = FALSE, skip_get_token = FALSE;
    8582             :

    8586             :     if (curr_token == tok_virtual) {
    8587             :       if (*is_virtual) {
    8588             :         pos_error(ec_dupl_decl_specifier, &pos_curr_token);
    8589             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    8590             :       } else if (is_immediate_managed_class_type(type_ptr)) {
    8591             :         pos_error(ec_virtual_base_for_managed_class, &pos_curr_token);
    8592             :       } else if (type_ptr->variant.class_struct_union.is_interface) {
    8593             :         pos_error(ec_interface_cannot_have_virtual_base, &pos_curr_token);
    8594             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    8595             :       } else {
    8596             :         *is_virtual = TRUE;
