   28775             : 
   28776             : static void check_quasi_overrides(a_class_def_state_ptr  cdsp)
   28777             : /*
   28778             : Check all entries describing "quasi-overrides" and issue diagnostics for any
   28779             : that are not irrelevant due to actual overrides. 
   28780             : */
   28781             : {
   28782             :   a_quasi_override_descr_ptr  qodp;
   28783             :   a_type_ptr                  class_type = cdsp->class_type;
   28784             : 
   28785             :   check_assertion(cli_or_cx_enabled);
   28786             :   /* Check each quasi-override in turn. */
   28787             :   for (qodp = cdsp->quasi_overrides; qodp != NULL; qodp = qodp->next) {
   28788             :     a_routine_ptr     base_rp = qodp->base_member->variant.routine.ptr;
   28789             :     a_routine_ptr     orp = base_rp;
   28790             :     a_base_class_ptr  obcp = qodp->base_class;
   28791             :     find_final_overrider(&obcp, &orp);
   28792             :     if (orp != base_rp) {
   28793             :       /* The "quasi-overridden" function is really overridden.  No
   28794             :          diagnostic needed. */
   28795             :       goto next_quasi_override;
   28796             :     }  /* if */
   28797             :     /* Issue the diagnostic corresponding to the cause of this entry. */
   28798             :     if (qodp->return_type_mismatch) {
   28799             :       pos_syty_warning(ec_different_return_type_on_virtual_function_override,
   28800             :                        &qodp->diag_pos, qodp->base_member,
   28801             :                        skip_typerefs(base_rp->type)
   28802             :                                                ->variant.routine.return_type);
   28803             :     } else if (qodp->missing_virtual_specifier) {
   28804             :       an_error_code  err_code = ec_virtual_required_for_base_override;
   28805             :       if (is_cli_interface_type(qodp->base_class->type)) {
   28806             :         err_code = ec_virtual_required_for_interface_implementation;
   28807             :       }  /* if */
   28808             :       pos_sy_error(err_code, &qodp->diag_pos, qodp->base_member); 
   28809             :     } else if (qodp->reduced_access) {
   28810             :       pos_sy_warning(ec_overriding_reduces_accessibility_in_managed_type,
   28811             :                      &qodp->diag_pos, qodp->base_member); 
   28812             :     } else if (qodp->nonpublic_interface_match) {
   28813             :       pos_sy_warning(ec_nonpublic_implicit_interface_match, &qodp->diag_pos,
   28814             :                      qodp->base_member); 
   28815             :     } else {
   28816             :       unexpected_condition();
   28817             :     }  /* if */
   28818             :     if (!class_type->variant.class_struct_union.is_generic_constraint) {
   28819             :       /* Since an interface member was not overridden, an error should be
   28820             :          issued indicating that the interface was not implemented.
   28821             :          (Generic constraint types aren't required to implement all
   28822             :          interface members.) */
   28823             :       expect_error();
   28824             :     }  /* if */
   28825             : next_quasi_override:;
   28826             :   }  /* for */ 
   28827             :   free_quasi_override_descr_list(&cdsp->quasi_overrides);
   28828             : }  /* check_quasi_overrides */
   28829             : 
   28830             : 
   28831             : void check_initonly_members(a_type_ptr  class_type,
   28832             :                             a_boolean   static_ctor_def_seen)
   28833             : /*
   28834             : Traverse the static data members of the given class type and check whether the
   28835             : initonly members appear to be initialized.  If not, issue a diagnostic.  If
   28836             : static_ctor_def_seen is TRUE, this routine is called after the static
   28837             : constructor definition has been seen.  (If a static constructor has been
   28838             : declared but not defined, no diagnostic can be issued because the constructor
   28839             : could provide the needed initialization.)
   28840             : */
   28841             : {
   28842             :   a_symbol_ptr  static_ctor = symbol_supplement_for_class(class_type)
   28843             :                                                          ->static_constructor;
   28844             : 
   28845             :   if (static_ctor_def_seen || static_ctor == NULL ||
   28846             :       static_ctor->variant.routine.ptr->compiler_generated) {
   28847             :     a_variable_ptr  var = class_type_supp(class_type)->assoc_scope->variables;
   28848             :     for (; var != NULL; var = var->next) {
   28849             :       if (var->is_initonly && !var->initializer_in_class &&
   28850             :           !symbol_for(var)->value_has_been_set) {
   28851             :         pos_error(ec_initonly_static_data_member_not_initialized,
   28852             :                   &symbol_for(var)->decl_position);
   28853             :       }  /* if */
   28854             :     }  /* if */
   28855             :   }  /* for */
   28856             : }  /* check_initonly_members */
   28857             : 
   28858             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   28859             : 
   28860       11934 : static void wrapup_standard_layout_flag(a_type_ptr  class_type)
   28861             : /*
   28862             : Determine the final value of the "standard_layout" flag in the symbol
   28863             : supplement for the given class type.  This routine can only change the flag
   28864             : from TRUE to FALSE.
   28865             : */
   28866             : {
   28867       11934 :   a_symbol_ptr      class_sym = symbol_for(class_type);
   28868       11934 :   a_class_symbol_supplement_ptr
   28869       11934 :                     cssp = class_sym->variant.class_struct_union.extra_info;
   28870             : 
   28871       11934 :   if (class_type->variant.class_struct_union
   28872       11934 :                          .any_virtual_functions_including_in_base_classes ||
   28873       11386 :       class_type->variant.class_struct_union.any_virtual_base_classes ||
   28874             :       cssp->any_ref_member) {
   28875             :     /* A class with a virtual function, a virtual base, or a reference
   28876             :        member is not a standard-layout class. */
   28877         592 :     cssp->standard_layout = FALSE;
   28878             :   }  /* if */
   28879       11934 :   if (cssp->standard_layout &&
   28880       11342 :       !class_type->variant.class_struct_union.is_prototype_instantiation) {
   28881        6579 :     a_base_class_ptr  bcp = base_classes_of(class_type), bcp_with_data = NULL;
   28882        6579 :     a_field_ptr       first_field = 
   28883             :                             class_type->variant.class_struct_union.field_list;
   28884        9500 :     for (; bcp != NULL; bcp = bcp->next) {
   28885        2921 :       a_class_symbol_supplement_ptr  bcssp = symbol_for(bcp->type)
   28886             :                                       ->variant.class_struct_union.extra_info;
   28887        2921 :       if (bcp->ambiguous && !gpp_mode && !clang_mode) {
   28888             :         /* A standard-layout class can have at most one base class subobject
   28889             :            of any type.  This was clarified by the resolution of Core issue
   28890             :            1813.  Clang and GCC, however, do not currently implement that
   28891             :            resolution. */
   28892           0 :         cssp->standard_layout = FALSE;
   28893           0 :         break;
   28894        2921 :       } else if (bcp->direct && bcssp->any_nonstatic_data_members) {
   28895          10 :         if (first_field != NULL || bcp_with_data != NULL) {
   28896             :           /* If the derivation includes nonstatic data members, a base class
   28897             :              cannot.  Otherwise, at most one base class can do so. */
   28898           0 :           cssp->standard_layout = FALSE;
   28899           0 :           break;
   28900             :         } else {
   28901             :           bcp_with_data = bcp;
   28902             :         }  /* if */
   28903             :       }  /* if */
   28904        2921 :       if (first_field != NULL && (bcp->direct || !(gpp_mode || clang_mode))) {
   28905             :         /* The first field of a standard layout type cannot have the same type
   28906             :            as a base class.  (GCC and Clang don't consider indirect base
   28907             :            classes in this case.) */
   28908          41 :         a_type_ptr  etype = skip_array_types(first_field->type);
   28909          41 :         if (identical_types(bcp->type, etype)) {
   28910           0 :           cssp->standard_layout = FALSE;
   28911           0 :           break;
   28912             :         }  /* if */
   28913             :       }  /* if */
   28914             :     }  /* for */
   28915        6579 :     if (first_field != NULL) {
   28916             :       /* All fields of a standard layout type must be declared with the same
   28917             :          access. */
   28918        1087 :       an_access_specifier  access = first_field->source_corresp.access;
   28919        1087 :       a_field_ptr          fp = first_field->next;
   28920        3334 :       for (; fp != NULL; fp = fp->next) {
   28921        2247 :         if (fp->source_corresp.access != access) {
   28922           0 :           cssp->standard_layout = FALSE;
   28923           0 :           break;
   28924             :         }  /* if */
   28925             :       }  /* for */
   28926             :     }  /* if */
   28927             :   }  /* if */
   28928       11934 : }  /* wrapup_standard_layout_flag */
   28929             : 
   28930             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
   28931             : 
   28932             : static void check_cppcx_value_type_symbol(a_symbol_ptr sym)
   28933             : /*
   28934             : Check some constraints on the given member of a C++/CX value class.
   28935             : */
   28936             : {
   28937             :   a_boolean                    check = TRUE;
   28938             :   a_source_correspondence_ptr  scp;
   28939             : 
   28940             :   switch (sym->kind) {
   28941             :     case sk_static_data_member:
   28942             :       scp = &sym->variant.static_data_member.variable->source_corresp;
   28943             :       if (scp->access != (an_access_specifier)as_public) {
   28944             :         /* Public value types cannot have non-public data members in C++/CX
   28945             :            mode. */
   28946             :         pos_error(ec_nonpublic_data_member_in_public_cppcx_value_type,
   28947             :                   &sym->decl_position);
   28948             :       }  /* if */
   28949             :       check = FALSE;
   28950             :       break;
   28951             :     case sk_field:
   28952             :       scp = &sym->variant.variable.ptr->source_corresp;
   28953             :       if (scp->access != (an_access_specifier)as_public) {
   28954             :         /* Public value types cannot have non-public data members in C++/CX
   28955             :            mode. */
   28956             :         pos_error(ec_nonpublic_data_member_in_public_cppcx_value_type,
   28957             :                   &sym->decl_position);
   28958             :       }  /* if */
   28959             :       check = FALSE;
   28960             :       break;
   28961             :     case sk_member_function:
   28962             :       if (sym->variant.routine.ptr->compiler_generated) {
   28963             :         check = FALSE;
   28964             :       }  /* if */
   28965             :       break;
   28966             :     case sk_type:
   28967             :       if (sym->variant.type.is_injected_class_name) check = FALSE;
   28968             :       break;
   28969             :     case sk_overloaded_function:
   28970             :       {
   28971             :         a_symbol_ptr overload;
   28972             :         for (overload = sym->variant.overloaded_function.symbols;
   28973             :              overload != NULL;
   28974             :              overload = overload->next) {
   28975             :           check_cppcx_value_type_symbol(overload);
   28976             :         }  /* for */
   28977             :         check = FALSE;
   28978             :       }
   28979             :       break;
   28980             :     case sk_property_set:
   28981             :       {
   28982             :         check = FALSE;
   28983             :       }
   28984             :       break;
   28985             :     case sk_projection:
   28986             :       /* Projection symbols shouldn't exist in value type classes since
   28987             :          value type inheritance is illegal in C++/CX mode.  However, this
   28988             :          can still happen when compiling invalid code. */
   28989             :       check = FALSE;
   28990             :       break;
   28991             :     default:
   28992             :       check_assertion(source_corresp_entry_for_symbol(sym) != NULL);
   28993             :       break;
   28994             :   }  /* switch */
   28995             :   if (check && source_corresp_entry_for_symbol(sym)->access ==
   28996             :                                              (an_access_specifier)as_public) {
   28997             :     /* A symbol that is not a static data member nor field, but is public in a
   28998             :        C++/CX value type.  This is invalid in C++/CX mode. */
   28999             :     pos_error(ec_public_nondata_member_in_public_cppcx_value_type,
   29000             :               &sym->decl_position);
   29001             :   }  /* if */
   29002             : }  /* check_cppcx_value_type_symbol */
   29003             : 
   29004             : 
   29005             : static void check_cppcx_value_type_symbols(a_type_ptr class_type)
   29006             : /*
   29007             : Check some constraints on the members of the given C++/CX value class.
   29008             : */
   29009             : {
   29010             :   check_assertion(cppcx_enabled && is_value_class_type(class_type));
   29011             :   if (class_has_public_assembly_visibility(class_type) &&
   29012             :       !is_nonpublic_nested_class(class_type)) {
   29013             :     /* Base classes do not need to be checked since inheritance is
   29014             :        not allowed for value types in C++/CX mode. */
   29015             :     a_symbol_ptr  sym = symbol_supplement_for_class(class_type)->symbols;
   29016             :     for (; sym != NULL; sym = sym->next_in_scope) {
   29017             :       check_cppcx_value_type_symbol(sym);
   29018             :     }  /* for */
   29019             :   }  /* if */
   29020             : }  /* check_cppcx_value_type_symbols */
   29021             : 
   29022             : 
   29023             : static void inject_special_platform_string_constructor(
   29024             :                                            a_class_def_state_ptr  class_state)
   29025             : /*
   29026             : Injects the Platform::String::String(__abi_HSTRING__* h) constructor into the
   29027             : C++/CX string class.
   29028             : */
   29029             : {
   29030             :   a_symbol_locator    loc;
   29031             :   a_member_decl_info  decl_info;
   29032             :   a_func_info_block   func_info;

   29034             :   a_type_ptr          abi_hstring_type = type_symbol_type(
   29035             :                                         cli_symbol_from_kind(csk_abi_hstring));
   29036             :   a_routine_type_supplement_ptr
   29037             :                       rtsp;
   29038             : 
   29039             :   /* Initialize info structures. */
   29040             :   clear_func_info(&func_info);
   29041             :   initialize_member_decl_info(&decl_info, &null_source_position);

   29045             :                                      &loc,

   29047             :                                      /*is_static_ctor=*/FALSE);

   29049             :   rout_type = make_routine_type(void_type(),
   29050             :                                 make_pointer_type(abi_hstring_type),
   29051             :                                 /*param2_type=*/NULL, /*param3_type=*/NULL,
   29052             :                                 /*param4_type=*/NULL);
   29053             :   rtsp = rout_type->variant.routine.extra_info;
   29054             :   rtsp->assoc_routine_is_ctor = TRUE;
   29055             :   rtsp->this_class = class_type;
   29056             :   rtsp->prototyped = TRUE;
   29057             :   decl_info.is_constructor = TRUE;
   29058             :   decl_info.decl_state.type = rout_type;
   29059             : #if GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS
   29060             :   func_info.declared_type = rout_type;
   29061             : #endif /* GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS */
   29062             :   /* Do not mark this constructor as compiler-generated: it is more trouble
   29063             :      than it's worth.  This injection should be as-if the declaration came
   29064             :      from metadata. */

   29066             :                        /*compiler_generated=*/FALSE);

   29070             : static void inject_unnamed_virtual_function(
   29071             :                                             a_class_def_state_ptr  class_state)
   29072             : /*
   29073             : Inject an unnamed virtual function into the type class_state->class_type.
   29074             : */
   29075             : {
   29076             :   a_symbol_locator    loc;
   29077             :   a_member_decl_info  decl_info;

   29091             :                                 /*param3_type=*/NULL, /*param4_type=*/NULL);
   29092             :   rtsp = rout_type->variant.routine.extra_info;

   29098             : #endif /* GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS */
   29099             :   /* Mark the routine as virtual. */
   29100             :   decl_info.decl_state.dso_flags |= DSO_VIRTUAL;

   29106             : 
   29107             : a_symbol_ptr make_and_enter_abi_member_function_symbol(
   29108             :                                                 a_symbol_locator  *loc,
   29109             :                                                 a_type_ptr        class_type)
   29110             : /*
   29111             : Create and enter a member function symbol whose name is described by *loc
   29112             : into class_type.  (This is a special "__abi_..." member with no parameters
   29113             : that returns type long.)
   29114             : */
   29115             : {
   29116             :   a_func_info_block              func_info;
   29117             :   a_member_decl_info             decl_info;
   29118             :   a_decl_parse_state_ptr         dps = &decl_info.decl_state;
   29119             :   a_type_ptr                     rout_type;
   29120             :   a_routine_type_supplement_ptr  rstp;
   29121             :   a_class_def_state              class_state;
   29122             :   a_symbol_ptr                   sym;
   29123             :   a_scope_ptr                    scope;
   29124             :   a_memory_region_number         saved_mem_region;
   29125             : 
   29126             :   /* Ensure that all IL allocations take place at file scope. */
   29127             :   switch_to_file_scope_region(&saved_mem_region);
   29128             :   /* Initialize variables. */
   29129             :   clear_func_info(&func_info);
   29130             :   initialize_member_decl_info(&decl_info, &null_source_position);
   29131             :   initialize_class_def_state(class_type, &class_state);
   29132             :   /* Get the IL scope for the class. */
   29133             :   scope = class_type_supp(class_type)->assoc_scope;
   29134             :   /* Push enough context for a call to decl_member_function to succeed.
   29135             :      We won't be performing any lookups beyond direct class members in this
   29136             :      function (the caller has ensured that these will fail to find a symbol)
   29137             :      and we won't reference any template/generic parameters (if applicable) so
   29138             :      it is not necessary to set up the stack for lookups; however, we do need
   29139             :      the symbol table set up and the class's il_scope available to add members
   29140             :      so an sck_class_reactivation is insufficient.  This is similar to how we
   29141             :      set up context for partial classes (though in the latter case, we actually
   29142             :      should be setting up the stack for lookups, but we don't currently). */
   29143             :   (void)push_scope((a_scope_kind)sck_class_struct_union, scope->number,
   29144             :                    class_type, (a_routine_ptr)NULL);
   29145             :   /* Set up the routine type. */
   29146             :   rout_type = make_routine_type(integer_type((an_integer_kind)ik_long),
   29147             :                                 /*param1_type=*/NULL, /*param2_type=*/NULL,
   29148             :                                 /*param3_type=*/NULL, /*param4_type=*/NULL);
   29149             :   rstp = rout_type->variant.routine.extra_info;
   29150             :   rstp->has_ellipsis = TRUE;
   29151             :   rstp->prototyped = TRUE;
   29152             :   rstp->this_class = class_type;
   29153             :   set_routine_calling_method_flag(rout_type, &null_source_position);
   29154             :   dps->type = rout_type;
   29155             :   /* Declare the member function. */
   29156             :   decl_member_function(loc, &func_info, &class_state,
   29157             :                        &decl_info, /*compiler_generated=*/TRUE);
   29158             :   sym = dps->sym;
   29159             :   pop_scope();
   29160             :   /* Switch back to the original memory region. */
   29161             :   switch_back_to_original_region(saved_mem_region);
   29162             :   return sym;
   29163             : }  /* make_and_enter_abi_member_function_symbol */
   29164             :

   29166             : 
   29167             : static a_boolean has_nonliteral_type_subobject(a_type_ptr  class_type)
   29168             : /*
   29169             : Return TRUE if the given class type has a field or direct base class that is
   29170             : not a literal type.
   29171             : */
   29172             : {
   29173             :   a_boolean         result = FALSE;
   29174             :   a_field_ptr       fp;
   29175             :   a_base_class_ptr  bcp;
   29176             : 
   29177             :   for (bcp = base_classes_of(class_type); bcp != NULL; bcp = bcp->next) {
   29178             :     /* Check if the base classes include a nonliteral class type.  Exclude
   29179             :        nonreal bases, and also incomplete bases (which are possible in
   29180             :        Microsoft-mode nonreal instantiations). */
   29181             :     if (bcp->direct && !bcp->type->incomplete &&
   29182             :         !bcp->type->variant.class_struct_union.is_nonreal_class &&
   29183             :         !is_literal_type(bcp->type)) {
   29184             :       result = TRUE;
   29185             :       break;
   29186             :     }  /* if */
   29187             :   }  /* for */
   29188             :   if (!result) {
   29189             :     fp = class_type->variant.class_struct_union.field_list;
   29190             :     fp = next_proper_initializable_field(fp);
   29191             :     for (; fp != NULL; fp = next_proper_initializable_field(fp->next)) {
   29192             :       if (!fp->compiler_generated && !could_be_literal_type(fp->type)) {
   29193             :         result = TRUE;
   29194             :         break;
   29195             :       }  /* if */
   29196             :     }  /* for */
   29197             :   }  /* if */
   29198             :   return result;
   29199             : }  /* has_nonliteral_type_subobject */
   29200             : 
   29201             : 
   29202        7636 : void set_literal_type_flag(a_type_ptr  type)
   29203             : /*
   29204             : Ensure either the known_to_be_a_literal_type or known_not_to_be_a_literal_type
   29205             : flag is set in the class symbol supplement of the given type.
   29206             : */
   29207             : {
   29208        7636 :   a_class_symbol_supplement_ptr
   29209        7636 :               cssp = symbol_for(type)->variant.class_struct_union.extra_info;
   29210             : 
   29211        7636 :   if (cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type ||
   29212             :       cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type) {
   29213             :     /* We already know whether this type is a literal type. */
   29214             :   } else {
   29215             :     /* Check the various constraints on literal class types: */
   29216        7636 :     if (is_immediate_managed_class_type(type)) {
   29217             :       /* Don't treat managed class types as literal types. */
   29218             :       cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29219        7636 :     } else if (has_nontrivial_destructor(cssp)) {
   29220             :       /* Literal class types must have trivial destructors. */
   29221         757 :       cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29222        6879 :     } else if (type->variant.class_struct_union.any_volatile_member) {
   29223             :       /* Literal class types cannot have volatile subobjects. */
   29224           0 :       cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29225        6879 :     } else if (type->variant.class_struct_union.any_virtual_base_classes) {
   29226             :       /* Literal class types cannot have virtual base classes. */
   29227           0 :       cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29228        6879 :     } else if (has_nonliteral_type_subobject(type)) {
   29229             :       /* Literal class types cannot have a subobject of nonliteral type. */
   29230          12 :       cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29231        6867 :     } else if (cssp->is_class_aggregate) {
   29232             :       /* Aggregate class types are literal types if they meet the previous
   29233             :          constraints. */
   29234        3872 :       cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29235        2995 :     } else if ((cssp->trivial_default_constructor != NULL &&
   29236             :                 cssp->trivial_default_constructor
   29237        2162 :                     ->variant.routine.ptr->is_constexpr) ||
   29238         836 :                (cssp->constructor == NULL &&
   29239         622 :                 !type->variant.class_struct_union.has_zero_init_component)) {
   29240             :       /* A constexpr trivial default constructor makes the class a literal
   29241             :          type. */
   29242        2778 :       cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29243         217 :     } else if (class_type_supp(type)->anonymous_union_kind !=
   29244             :                                           (an_anonymous_union_kind)auk_none) {
   29245             :       /* Anonymous unions don't have constructors per se (and hence no
   29246             :          constexpr constructor will be found), but we can treat them like
   29247             :          aggregates in this context. */
   29248           0 :       cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29249         217 :     } else if (!constexpr_enabled) {
   29250             :       /* The C++11 notion of a literal type doesn't really make sense without
   29251             :          constexpr, but some (Microsoft) modes support the __is_literal_type
   29252             :          predicate without supporting constexpr.  The criteria above could
   29253             :          conceivably apply without considering constexpr, but if we get here
   29254             :          we'll treat the class type as a non-literal type. */
   29255           0 :       cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29256             :     } else {
   29257             :       /* Check if the type has a constexpr constructor or constructor template
   29258             :          that isn't a move/copy constructor.  The standard also requires that
   29259             :          all field initializers be constant-expressions, but that is likely a
   29260             :          defect in the standard (leading to difficult ordering problems when
   29261             :          a generated default constructor is involved). */
   29262         217 :       if (cssp->constructor != NULL &&
   29263             :           cssp->has_constexpr_nonstatic_member_function) {
   29264             :         /* Look for a constexpr constructor that is not a copy or move
   29265             :            constructor. */
   29266         112 :         a_symbol_ptr  sym = cssp->constructor;
   29267         112 :         a_boolean     is_list = FALSE;
   29268         112 :         if (symbol_is(sym, sk_overloaded_function)) {
   29269         112 :           is_list = TRUE;
   29270         112 :           sym = sym->variant.overloaded_function.symbols;
   29271             :         }  /* if */
   29272         816 :         for (; sym != NULL; sym = is_list ? sym->next : (a_symbol_ptr)NULL) {
   29273         464 :           if (symbol_is(sym, sk_member_function)) {
   29274         390 :             a_routine_ptr         rp = sym->variant.routine.ptr;
   29275         390 :             a_type_qualifier_set  qualifiers;
   29276         706 :             if (rp->is_constexpr &&
   29277         316 :                 !is_copy_constructor_type(rp->type, type, &qualifiers,
   29278             :                                           /*include_move_ctors=*/TRUE,
   29279             :                                           /*is_declarative_context=*/TRUE)) {
   29280         112 :               cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29281         112 :               break;
   29282             :             }  /* if */
   29283          74 :           } else if (symbol_is(sym, sk_function_template) &&
   29284          74 :                      sym->variant.template_info->variant.function.routine
   29285             :                                                ->is_constexpr) {
   29286           0 :             cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29287           0 :             break;
   29288             :           }  /* if */
   29289             :         }  /* for */
   29290             :       }  /* if */
   29291         217 :       if (!cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type &&
   29292         217 :           !cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type &&
   29293         105 :           !cssp->scanning_field_initializer &&
   29294         105 :           check_if_constexpr_generated_default_constructor(type)) {
   29295             :         /* The generated default constructor will be constexpr, so the type
   29296             :            can be treated as a literal type.  Note we don't try to test for
   29297             :            a constexpr generated default constructor if we are already in
   29298             :            the process of scanning field initializer, since that might yield
   29299             :            an incorrect result. */
   29300           0 :         cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29301             :       }  /* if */
   29302         217 :       if (!strict_ansi_mode &&
   29303         217 :           !cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type &&
   29304             :           !cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type) {
   29305             :         /* Consider the following case:
   29306             :              struct A { int a; };
   29307             :              struct B: A {};
   29308             :            Under C++11/C++14 rules, B is not a literal type because it's not
   29309             :            an aggregate type and it doesn't have a non-copy/move constexpr
   29310             :            constructor.  However, value-initialization does produce a constant
   29311             :            B value, and because of this existing practice is to treat B as a
   29312             :            literal type (this is also core issue 1452). */
   29313         105 :         a_constant_ptr  val = local_constant();
   29314         147 :         if (!cssp->has_user_provided_default_constructor &&
   29315          42 :             make_value_initialized_constant(type, val)) {
   29316           3 :           cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29317             :         }  /* if */
   29318         105 :         release_local_constant(&val);
   29319             :       }  /* if */
   29320         217 :       if (!cssp->known_to_be_a_literal_type) {
   29321             :         /* If we haven't concluded that the type is a literal type by now, it
   29322             :            isn't a literal type. */
   29323         102 :         cssp->known_not_to_be_a_literal_type = TRUE;
   29324             :       }  /* if */
   29325             :     }  /* if */
   29326             :   }  /* if */
   29327        7636 : }  /* set_literal_type_flag */
   29328             : 
   29329             : 
   29330       17372 : static void complete_class_definition(a_type_ptr         class_type,
   29331             :                                       a_scope_depth      effective_decl_level,
   29332             :                                       a_class_def_state  *class_state)
   29333             : /*
   29334             : We have seen the complete definition of class_type belonging to scope level
   29335             : effective_decl_level.  Perform various postprocessing steps such as computing
   29336             : the layout and synthesizing special members (C++).  *class_state holds some
   29337             : bits of information that were acquired while parsing.  Note that fixup
   29338             : processing (e.g., for default arguments of member functions) has not been done
   29339             : at this point yet.  For tasks that must occur after that processing, see
   29340             : wrap_up_class_definition.
   29341             : */

   29573       18542 : void check_for_file_with_unterminated_type_definition(
   29574             :                                                   a_source_position  *end_pos)
   29575             : /*
   29576             : end_pos is the position of the last token of a class type or enum type
   29577             : definition (usually the position of the closing brace, although GNU attributes
   29578             : can make it the position of a parenthesis closing the attribute).  If the
   29579             : current token (which must be the subsequent token; usually a declarator or a
   29580             : semicolon) is in a different file, issue a warning for what is likely going to
   29581             : be a syntax error showing up in the next file.  I.e., something like:
   29582             : 
   29583             :         struct S {}  // Warn on the suspect end-of-file condition here.
   29584             :         # 1 "defs.c"
   29585             :         S* f();  // Missing semicolon error issued here.
   29586             : */
   29587             : {
   29588       18542 :   if (end_pos->seq != pos_curr_token.seq &&
   29589          39 :       depth_innermost_instantiation_scope == NO_SCOPE_DEPTH) {

   29591             :        different lines.  (This can also happen with template instantiations;
   29592             :        hence the condition on depth_innermost_instantiation_scope.)  Now check
   29593             :        whether these two position correspond to different files (taking into
   29594             :        account any #line directives). */
   29595           3 :     a_line_number      line1, line2;
   29596           3 :     a_boolean          eos1, eos2;

   29601             :                                /*physical_line=*/FALSE);
   29602             :     /* We cannot just compare src1 and src2 for equality because #line
   29603             :        directives create new a_source_file entries.  E.g.:
   29604             :              struct S {}
   29605             :              #line 100
   29606             :              x;  // Should not trigger a diagnostic, and yet src1 != src2.
   29607             :        Instead, we perform a file name comparison. */

   29609           0 :         src1->file_name != NULL && src2->file_name != NULL &&

   29619       17052 : static void record_max_member_alignment_if_needed(a_type_ptr  class_type)
   29620             : /*
   29621             : If a "#pragma pack(n)" directive or an equivalent command-line option is in
   29622             : effect, record the implied maximum member alignment in the given class (which
   29623             : is about to be defined).  If any packing attributes have already been applied
   29624             : the presence of the directive is recorded as an internal attribute: It usually
   29625             : has no effect, but in some GNU modes the attribute is ignored for some fields
   29626             : (and the internal attribute is then consulted to determine the effective
   29627             : alignment of those fields).
   29628             : */
   29629             : {
   29630       17052 :   a_targ_alignment  max_member_alignment = 
   29631       17052 :                                     current_max_alignment_for_class_members();

   29633       17052 :   if (max_member_alignment != 0) {
   29634             :     /* The maximum alignment of a member is limited by a pragma or by a
   29635             :        command-line directive.  If an attribute has already been applied to
   29636             :        achieve the same effect, record this maximum in the class directly;
   29637             :        otherwise, record it as an internal attribute. */
   29638           0 :     if (class_type->variant.class_struct_union.max_member_alignment == 0) {
   29639           0 :       class_type->variant.class_struct_union.max_member_alignment =
   29640             :                                                          max_member_alignment;
   29641             :     } else {
   29642             :       /* Create an internal attribute representing the maximum member alignment

   29644           0 :       an_attribute_ptr        ap = alloc_attribute();

   29663             : 
   29664             : 
   29665             : #if !EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL || !GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS
   29666             : /*ARGSUSED*/ /* decl_pos_block is not used unless extra source-position
   29667             :                 information is being recorded in the IL.
   29668             :                 il_template_entry is not used unless source sequence entries
   29669             :                 are being generated. */
   29670             : #endif /* !EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL || !GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS */
   29671       17052 : a_boolean scan_class_definition(a_type_ptr          class_type,
   29672             :                                 a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
   29673             :                                 a_scope_depth       effective_decl_level,
   29674             :                                 a_boolean           is_partial,
   29675             :                                 a_boolean           is_local_class,
   29676             :                                 a_boolean           delayed_nested_class_def,
   29677             :                                 a_boolean           is_template_instantiation,
   29678             :                                 a_boolean           is_template_specialization,
   29679             :                                 a_template_ptr      il_template_entry,
   29680             :                                 a_decl_pos_block    *decl_pos_block)
   29681             : /*
   29682             : Scan the body of a class definition, including the base classes list.
   29683             : class_type points to the type entry of the class, struct, or union whose
   29684             : definition is to be scanned.  *dps describes the declaration that the
   29685             : definition is part of (NULL for a class template instantiation other than
   29686             : a prototype instantiation, as well as for a class definition processed by
   29687             : get_definition_of_class).  effective_decl_level indicates the name scope
   29688             : to which the class declaration belongs.  is_partial indicates that this is
   29689             : just a part of a class definition (possible in C++/CX only): Such partial
   29690             : definitions are cached until all the partial class bodies are available.
   29691             : is_local_class is TRUE if the class definition appears inside a function
   29692             : body.  delayed_nested_class_def is TRUE if the class is a nested class
   29693             : whose parent class definition has already been completed (C++ only).
   29694             : is_template_instantiation is TRUE when a template is being instantiated
   29695             : either for the purpose of producing the prototype instantiation or for
   29696             : generating a real instantiation.  It is also TRUE for nested classes when
   29697             : their definition appears outside of the class template.  If a prototype
   29698             : instantiation is produced, il_template_entry is set to the template entry
   29699             : for the class template definition; otherwise it is NULL.
   29700             : is_template_specialization is TRUE for explicit specializations of template
   29701             : classes.
   29702             : */
   29703             : {
   29704       17052 :   a_boolean                        err = FALSE;
   29705       17052 :   a_symbol_ptr                     tag_sym = symbol_for(class_type);
   29706       17052 :   a_scope_ptr                      scope_ptr;
   29707       17052 :   a_class_symbol_supplement_ptr    cssp;
   29708       17052 :   a_class_type_supplement_ptr      ctsp = class_type_supp(class_type);
   29709       17052 :   a_routine_fixup_ptr              saved_routine_fixup = NULL;
   29710       17052 :   a_template_symbol_supplement_ptr class_tssp;
   29711       17052 :   a_token_sequence_number          last_token_number_of_definition;
   29712       17052 :   a_class_def_state                class_state;
   29713       17052 :   a_boolean                        skip_semicolon_check;
   29714       17052 :   a_type_ptr                       dummy_type;
   29715       17052 :   a_boolean                        instantiation_scope_pushed = FALSE;
   29716       17052 :   a_boolean                        is_in_class_specialization;
   29717       17052 :   a_pack_alignment_state           saved_pack_alignment_state;
   29718       17052 :   a_boolean                        need_restore_pack_alignment_state = FALSE;
   29719       17052 :   a_boolean                        class_is_in_valid_scope;
   29720             : #if GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS
   29721             : #if TEMPLATE_INSTANTIATIONS_IN_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS
   29722       17052 :   a_scope_depth                   class_scope_depth;
   29723             : #endif /* TEMPLATE_INSTANTIATIONS_IN_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS */
   29724             : #endif /* GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS */
   29725             : #if IA64_ABI
   29726       17052 :   a_routine_ptr                   rout;
   29727             : #endif /* IA64_ABI */

   30517             :       }  /* if */

   30552             :        which the class being defined belongs.  This has to be done before the
   30553             :        call to pop_template_instantiation_scope -- otherwise, the insert point
   30554             :        is wrong for the class body.  Note also that, at this point, the depth
   30555             :        of the innermost namespace scope will not be on the top of the stack if
   30556             :        an extra instantiation scope was pushed. */
   30557       17052 :     scope_stack[class_scope_depth].ss_list_instantiation_insert_point = NULL;
   30558             : #endif /* TEMPLATE_INSTANTIATIONS_IN_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS */
   30559             : #endif /* GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS */
   30560             :      /* Perform any deferred access checks from the enclosing scope so that
   30561             :         any references from the base-specifiers will be evaluated in the
   30562             :         context of the complete class.  For example
   30563             :            class B { protected: class N {} };
   30564             :            class D: B::N, B {};
   30565             :         In C++03 this is an error because when we see B::N, B is not yet a
   30566             :         base and hence we have no special access to a protected member.  In
   30567             :         C++11, access checking in base specifiers must be deferred until
   30568             :         all bases are known, and hence this example is valid.  Microsoft
   30569             :         compilers do something in between in that this example results in
   30570             :         an error, but access checking for names in template arguments is
   30571             :         apparently deferred.  E.g., the following is accepted by Microsoft
   30572             :         compilers (with B as above):
   30573             :             template<class T> struct X {};
   30574             :             struct E: B, X<B::N> {};
   30575             :         As an approximation of that behavior we use the C++11 rules in
   30576             :         Microsoft C++ mode. */
   30577       17052 :     if (gpp_mode && gnu_version >= 30400 && is_template_instantiation) {
   30578             :       /* g++ has a bug that simply ignores access errors in the base
   30579             :          specifier list of a class template. */
   30580        8695 :       if (access_check_depth != NO_SCOPE_DEPTH) {
   30581        8695 :         f_discard_deferred_access_checks(access_check_depth);
   30582             :       }  /* if */

   30783             : 
   30784           0 : static void scan_init_capture(a_lambda_ptr           lambda,
   30785             :                               a_boolean              is_ref,
   30786             :                               a_source_position_ptr  capture_pos)
   30787             : /*
   30788             : Scan a C++14-style init-capture for the given lambda.  If is_ref is TRUE, an
   30789             : ampersand has already been scanned for this capture.  For example, in
   30790             :       [i = 0](int p) mutable { i += p; return i; }
   30791             : "i = 0" is the init-capture.  It eventually will translate to a field in the
   30792             : closure class that will be initialized as indicated.  However, since the
   30793             : closure class is not being defined yet, the initializer is prescanned and the
   30794             : result of that prescan is recorded in a dynamically allocated declaration parse
   30795             : state block.
   30796             : 
   30797             : *capture_pos is the position to record for the capture.
   30798             : */
   30799             : {
   30800           0 :   a_lambda_capture_ptr  lcp;
   30801           0 :   a_decl_parse_state    *dps = alloc_decl_parse_state();
   30802           0 :   a_symbol_header_ptr   sym_hdr = locator_for_curr_id.symbol_header;
   30803           0 :   a_boolean             err = FALSE;
   30804             : 
   30805           0 :   if (diagnose_duplicate_capture(lambda, sym_hdr, capture_pos)) {
   30806             :     /* Allocate an unattached lambda capture entry for the error case. */
   30807           0 :     lcp = alloc_lambda_capture();
   30808           0 :     err = TRUE;
   30809             :   } else {

   30823           0 :   dps->is_init_capture = TRUE;

   30872             : 
   30873             : 
   30874           0 : static void scan_lambda_capture_list(a_lambda_ptr  lambda)
   30875             : /*
   30876             : Scan the capture list for a lambda construct associated with lambda.  The
   30877             : caller has already moved past the '[', and this routine leaves the trailing
   30878             : ']' to be consumed by the caller.  The grammar to be parsed is thus:
   30879             : 
   30880             :     lambda-capture(opt)
   30881             : 
   30882             :     lambda-capture:
   30883             :         capture-default | capture-list | capture-default ',' capture-list
   30884             : 
   30885             :     capture-default:
   30886             :         '&' | '='
   30887             : 
   30888             :     capture-list:
   30889             :         capture | capture-list ',' capture
   30890             : 
   30891             :     capture:
   30892             :         simple-capture | init-capture
   30893             : 
   30894             :     simple-capture:
   30895             :         identifier | '&' identifier | 'this' | '*' 'this'
   30896             : 
   30897             :     init-capture:
   30898             :         identifier initializer | '&' identifier initializer
   30899             : */
   30900             : {
   30901           0 :   a_token_kind       tok_after_ref = tok_error;
   30902           0 :   a_source_position  capture_pos;
   30903             : #if EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL
   30904           0 :   a_source_position  capture_end_pos;
   30905             : #endif /* EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL */
   30906             : 
   30907           0 :   add_stop_token(tok_comma);
   30908           0 :   if (curr_token == tok_ampersand) tok_after_ref = next_token();
   30909             :   /* Look for a capture-default token. */
   30910           0 :   if (curr_token == tok_assign ||
   30911           0 :       (curr_token == tok_ampersand &&
   30912           0 :        (tok_after_ref == tok_comma || tok_after_ref == tok_rbracket))) {
   30913           0 :     lambda->has_capture_default = TRUE;
   30914           0 :     lambda->default_is_by_reference = (curr_token == tok_ampersand);
   30915             :     /* Skip the & or =, and if the next token is a comma, skip that too. */
   30916           0 :     (void)get_token();
   30917           0 :     if (curr_token == tok_comma) {
   30918           0 :       a_source_position  pos_first_comma;
   30919           0 :       pos_first_comma = pos_curr_token;
   30920           0 :       (void)get_token();
   30921           0 :       if (curr_token == tok_rbracket) {
   30922             :         /* Something like "[ = , ](){}".  Issue an error. */
   30923           0 :         pos_diagnostic(es_discretionary_error, ec_nonstd_extra_comma,
   30924             :                        &pos_first_comma);
   30925             :       }  /* if */
   30926             :     }  /* if */
   30927             :   }  /* if */
   30928             :   /* Now scan the explicit captures. */
   30929           0 :   if (curr_token != tok_rbracket) {
   30930           0 :     do {
   30931           0 :       a_pack_expansion_stack_entry_ptr pesep;
   30932           0 :       a_boolean                        any_more, check_duplicate = TRUE;
   30933           0 :       any_more = begin_potential_pack_expansion_context(&pesep);

   30949           0 :           by_ref = TRUE;
   30950           0 :           (void)get_token();
   30951             :         }  /* if */

   30953             : #if EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL
   30954           0 :         capture_end_pos = end_pos_curr_token;
   30955             : #endif /* EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL */

   30957           0 :             (capture_star_this_enabled && curr_token == tok_star &&

   31062             :         }  /* if */
   31063           0 : capture_processed:
   31064           0 :         pedep = end_potential_pack_expansion_context(pesep,
   31065             :                                                      /*is_declarator=*/FALSE);
   31066           0 :         if (pedep != NULL && lcp != NULL) {

   31095             : static void push_closure_class(a_lambda_ptr           lambda,
   31096             :                                a_class_def_state_ptr  class_state)
   31097             : /*

   31124           0 : static void scan_optional_lambda_declarator(a_lambda_ptr        lambda,
   31125             :                                             a_func_info_block   *func_info,
   31126             :                                             a_member_decl_info  *decl_info,
   31127             :                                             a_tmpl_decl_state   *templ_state)
   31128             : /*
   31129             : For the given lambda, parse the (optional) declarator-like construct, which
   31130             : consists of a parameter list and, optionally, a mutable specifier, an exception
   31131             : specification, and/or a return type specification.  Return properties of the
   31132             : implied call operator in *func_info and *decl_info (both are initialized here).
   31133             : 
   31134             : This function also determines if this is a generic lambda.  If it is,
   31135             : *templ_state is initialized with the relevant state information and a
   31136             : corresponding template declaration scope is pushed.
   31137             : */
   31138             : {
   31139           0 :   a_decl_parse_state  *dps = &decl_info->decl_state;
   31140           0 :   a_decl_pos_block    *decl_pos_block = &decl_info->decl_pos_block;
   31141             : 
   31142           0 :   clear_func_info(func_info);
   31143           0 :   func_info->lambda = lambda;
   31144           0 :   initialize_member_decl_info(decl_info, &pos_curr_token);
   31145           0 :   decl_info->is_first_in_declarator_list = TRUE;
   31146           0 :   dps->specifiers_type = make_auto_type(&pos_curr_token,
   31147             :                                         /*is_decltype_auto=*/FALSE);
   31148           0 :   dps->type = dps->specifiers_type;
   31149           0 :   dps->start_pos = dps->specifiers_pos = pos_curr_token;
   31150           0 :   dps->in_class_scope = TRUE;
   31151           0 :   dps->declarator_start_pos = dps->declarator_pos = pos_curr_token;
   31152           0 :   dps->is_lambda = TRUE;
   31153           0 :   dps->first_decl = TRUE;
   31154           0 :   if (curr_token == tok_lparen) {
   31155             :     /* A parameter list presumably follows. */
   31156           0 :     add_stop_token(tok_lbrace);
   31157           0 :     if (generic_lambdas_enabled) {
   31158             :       /* Prescan the parameter list to look for one or more "auto" parameters
   31159             :          that would make this a generic lambda. */
   31160           0 :       prescan_lambda_parameter_clause(dps);
   31161           0 :       if (dps->variant.auto_params != NULL) {
   31162             :         /* At least one "auto" parameter was seen: Set up a member function
   31163             :            template context. */

   31166           0 :                                      ->is_generic_lambda_closure_class = TRUE;

   31179           0 :     lambda->explicit_return_type = dps->has_trailing_return_type;

   31183             :        construct was just an empty parameter list and the return type is
   31184             :        "auto" (in the C++14 sense). */

   31186             :                                              /*is_decltype_auto=*/FALSE);

   31191             :                                   /*param4_type=*/NULL);

   31196           0 :     dps->has_deducible_return_type = TRUE;
   31197             : #if GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS
   31198           0 :     func_info->declared_type = dps->type;
   31199             : #endif /* GENERATE_SOURCE_SEQUENCE_LISTS */
   31200             :   }  /* if */
   31201           0 : }  /* scan_optional_lambda_declarator */
   31202             : 
   31203             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
   31204             : 
   31205             : a_boolean is_lambda(void)
   31206             : /*
   31207             : The current token is a "[" that could be the start of a lambda, or in Microsoft
   31208             : mode could be the start of a Microsoft attribute.  Look ahead to determine
   31209             : whether this is a lambda.  Return TRUE if it is.
   31210             : */
   31211             : {
   31212             :   a_token_cache  cache;
   31213             :   a_boolean      result = TRUE;
   31214             : 
   31215             :   /* Skip the processing if lambdas are not enabled. */
   31216             :   if (!lambdas_enabled) {
   31217             :     result = FALSE;
   31218             :     goto done;
   31219             :   }  /* if */
   31220             :   check_assertion(curr_token == tok_lbracket);
   31221             :   clear_token_cache(&cache, /*reusable=*/FALSE);
   31222             :   cache_curr_token(&cache);
   31223             :   /* Get the token after the "[". */
   31224             :   (void)get_token();
   31225             :   if (curr_token == tok_assign || curr_token == tok_ampersand ||
   31226             :       curr_token == tok_rbracket || curr_token == tok_this) {
   31227             :     /* Something like "[=...", "[&...", "[]", or "[this...". Treat this as a
   31228             :        lambda. */
   31229             :   } else if (curr_token != tok_identifier) {
   31230             :     /* After the cases above have been excluded, both lambdas and Microsoft
   31231             :        attributes should have an identifier next.  If the next token is
   31232             :        not an identifier treat this as a lambda for error recovery purposes. */
   31233             :   } else {
   31234             :     /* The token is an identifier. */
   31235             :     a_token_kind  next_tok;
   31236             :     /* Skip past a comma-separated list of identifiers. */
   31237             :     for (;;) {
   31238             :       /* Cache the identifier, if any. */
   31239             :       if (curr_token != tok_identifier && curr_token != tok_this) break;
   31240             :       cache_curr_token(&cache);
   31241             :       (void)get_token();
   31242             :       if (variadic_templates_enabled && curr_token == tok_ellipsis) {
   31243             :         /* Allow the identifier to be followed by ... when variadic templates
   31244             :            are enabled. */
   31245             :         cache_curr_token(&cache);
   31246             :         (void)get_token();
   31247             :       }  /* if */
   31248             :       if (init_capture_enabled &&
   31249             :           (curr_token == tok_assign || curr_token == tok_lparen ||
   31250             :            curr_token == tok_lbrace)) {
   31251             :         /* A C++14-style "init-capture": Cache everything up until a comma or
   31252             :            a left bracket. */
   31253             :         a_token_set_array  stop_token_array;
   31254             :         clear_token_set_array(stop_token_array);
   31255             :         incr_token_set_array_element(stop_token_array, tok_comma);
   31256             :         incr_token_set_array_element(stop_token_array, tok_rbracket);
   31257             :         /* Also stop on a right brace or semicolon to keep from caching too far
   31258             :            in error cases. */
   31259             :         incr_token_set_array_element(stop_token_array, tok_rbrace);
   31260             :         incr_token_set_array_element(stop_token_array, tok_semicolon);
   31261             :         cache_token_stream_full(&cache, stop_token_array, CTS_COALESCE_IDS);
   31262             :       }  /* if */
   31263             :       if (curr_token != tok_comma) {
   31264             :         break;
   31265             :       } else {
   31266             :         /* Cache the comma and loop for the next (presumed) capture. */
   31267             :         cache_curr_token(&cache);
   31268             :         (void)get_token();
   31269             :       }  /* if */
   31270             :     }  /* for */
   31271             :     /* Note that next_token() is not called until we've looked at the current
   31272             :        token.  This is done to avoid caching an unquoted uuid. */
   31273             :     if ((curr_token == tok_assign || curr_token == tok_ampersand) &&
   31274             :         ((next_tok = next_token()) == tok_identifier ||
   31275             :          next_tok == tok_this)) {
   31276             :       /* We encountered "=x" or "&x".  Treat this is a lambda. */
   31277             :     } else if (curr_token == tok_rbracket) {
   31278             :       /* "[x]...": If the token after the right bracket is a "{" or "(",
   31279             :          assume this is a lambda. */
   31280             :       next_tok = next_token();
   31281             :       if (next_tok != tok_lbrace && next_tok != tok_lparen) result = FALSE;
   31282             :     } else if (curr_token == tok_colon_colon) {
   31283             :       /* "[x::...", which cannot be a lambda but could be an attribute. */
   31284             :       result = FALSE;
   31285             :     } else {
   31286             :       /* Something else not handled above.  Assume this to be an attribute. */
   31287             :       result = FALSE;
   31288             :     }  /* if */
   31289             :   }  /* if */
   31290             :   /* Rescan the tokens cached above. */
   31291             :   rescan_cached_tokens(&cache);
   31292             : done:
   31293             :   return result;
   31294             : }  /* is_lambda */
   31295             : 
   31296             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
   31297             : 
   31298           0 : static a_scope_depth decl_level_for_lambda_closure_class(a_boolean  *bad_scope)
   31299             : /*
   31300             : A lambda appears in the current scope context.  Return the scope depth at
   31301             : which the associated closure class should be declared.  Return in *bad_scope
   31302             : a flag that indicates whether or not the current scope is valid for a
   31303             : lambda.
   31304             : */
   31305             : {
   31306           0 :   a_scope_depth           previous_scope;
   31307           0 :   a_scope_stack_entry_ptr ssep;
   31308           0 :   a_boolean               scope_error = FALSE;
   31309             : 
   31310           0 :   for (ssep = scope_stack_entry_for(depth_scope_stack);;
   31311           0 :        ssep = scope_stack_entry_for(previous_scope)) {
   31312           0 :     previous_scope = ssep->previous_scope;
   31313           0 :     switch (ssep->kind) {
   31314           0 :       case sck_file:
   31315             :       case sck_block:
   31316             :       case sck_namespace:
   31317             :       case sck_namespace_extension:
   31318             :       case sck_class_struct_union:
   31319             :       case sck_condition:
   31320             :       case sck_function:
   31321             :       case sck_class_reactivation:
   31322             :       case sck_namespace_reactivation:
   31323           0 :         goto done;
   31324           0 :       case sck_instantiation_context:
   31325             :         /* We might see this while looking for a suitable scope after error
   31326             :            recovery. */
   31327           0 :         check_assertion(scope_error);
   31328             :         break;
   31329             :       case sck_template_instantiation:
   31330             :         /* For a template instantiation scope, keep following the
   31331             :            previous_scope links in the scope stack.   This will result in
   31332             :            the closure going in the namespace of the template definition.  This
   31333             :            case only comes up for lambdas in the initializer of template
   31334             :            static data members and default arguments of namespace scope
   31335             :            function templates. */
   31336             :         break;
   31337             :       case sck_func_prototype:
   31338             :         /* If a lambda appears in a function prototype scopes, its closure
   31339             :            type is treated as if it were defined in the nearest enclosing
   31340             :            non-function-prototype scope. */
   31341             :         break;
   31342             :       case sck_function_access:
   31343             :         /* Ignore this scope.  (It might enclose a function prototype scope
   31344             :            while parsing default arguments.) */
   31345             :         break;
   31346           0 :       case sck_template_declaration:
   31347             :       case sck_enum:
   31348             :         /* Prior to C++17, lambdas cannot appear in template parameter
   31349             :            lists nor in scoped enumeration definitions.  Otherwise, the
   31350             :            closure class will be promoted to the containing scope. */
   31351           0 :         if (!constexpr_lambdas_enabled) {
   31352           0 :           scope_error = TRUE;
   31353             :         }  /* if */
   31354             :         break;
   31355           0 :       default:
   31356             :         /* Scopes not covered above are unexpected, but it is safe to treat
   31357             :            them as errors. */
   31358           0 :         scope_error = TRUE;
   31359           0 :         break;
   31360             :     }  /* switch */
   31361             :   }  /* for */
   31362           0 : done:
   31363           0 :   if (scope_error) {
   31364             :     /* An error should have already been issued that a lambda is not allowed
   31365             :        in a constant expression (which must be the case for the invalid
   31366             :        scopes. */
   31367           0 :     expect_error();

   31369           0 :   *bad_scope = scope_error;
   31370           0 :   return scope_depth_of(ssep);
   31371             : }  /* decl_level_for_lambda_closure_class */
   31372             : 
   31373             : 
   31374           0 : static void finish_lambda_routine_processing(a_lambda_ptr  *p_lambda)
   31375             : /*

   31377             : completed.  Perform any final processing for the closure type's operator()
   31378             : (notably, IL lowering).
   31379             : In severe error cases, *p_lambda->lambda_routine can be NULL: Set *p_lambda to

   31383           0 :   a_lambda_ptr   lambda = *p_lambda;

   31431             :                                             a_calling_convention  call_conv,
   31432             :                                             a_source_position     *pos)
   31433             : /*
   31434             : Create a symbol locator for the static member of a lambda that permits a
   31435             : conversion to a pointer to function.  The static member will have the
   31436             : indicated calling convention (cc_default in non-Microsoft modes).  Record the
   31437             : given position in that locator.
   31438             : When the calling convention is cc_default, we call the static member function
   31439             : _FUN because that's what GCC does, and this can be an ABI issue.  For other
   31440             : calling conventions, a suffix is added (this only happens in Microsoft mode,
   31441             : where we don't attempt ABI emulation).

   31444           0 :   char      *name = (char*)"_FUN";

   31527             : 
   31528           0 : static void generate_lambda_conversion_function(
   31529             :                                              a_lambda_ptr          lambda,
   31530             :                                              a_class_def_state     *cdsp,
   31531             :                                              a_func_info_block     *func_info,
   31532             :                                              a_calling_convention  call_conv)
   31533             : /*
   31534             : Add a conversion function to the closure type (described by *cdsp) for the
   31535             : given lambda.  The caller has already determined that the given lambda doesn't
   31536             : have a capture list or default capture mode, and hence the synthesized
   31537             : "operator()" does not make use its "this" parameter.  The conversion function
   31538             : returns the address of a static member of the closure type that represents an
   31539             : alternative entry point for "operator()": It is also generated here and has
   31540             : the indicated calling convention (in Microsoft mode, pairs of functions are
   31541             : generated for several calling conventions).
   31542             : *func_info describes properties of the lambda's "operator()".
   31543             : */

   31545           0 :   a_routine_ptr       call_op = lambda->lambda_routine;

   31551           0 :   a_func_info_block   local_func_info;

   31561             :                                             source_sequence_entries_disallowed;

   31565             : 
   31566             :   /* Create a call type without an implicit "this" parameter (and not directly

   31637             : 
   31638           0 : static a_boolean lambda_has_conversion_function(a_lambda_ptr  lambda)
   31639             : /*
   31640             : Return whether the given lambda should have a conversion function.  Ordinarily,
   31641             : the conditions should be:
   31642             :   - no explicit capture
   31643             :   - no capture default
   31644             :   - the lambda call operator must exist (error recovery)
   31645             : However, earlier versions of the GCC compiler ignored the presence of a capture
   31646             : default as long as no implicit capture is created for it.
   31647             : */

   31649           0 :   return lambda->capture_list == NULL &&
   31650           0 :          (!lambda->has_capture_default ||
   31651           0 :           (gpp_mode && !clang_mode && gnu_version < 60200)) &&
   31652           0 :          lambda->lambda_routine != NULL;

   31655             : 
   31656           0 : static void generate_lambda_conversion_functions_if_needed(
   31657             :                                              a_lambda_ptr          lambda,
   31658             :                                              a_class_def_state     *cdsp,
   31659             :                                              a_func_info_block     *func_info)
   31660             : /*
   31661             : If the given lambda has a capture list of the form "[]", generate a conversion
   31662             : function for it (the conversion is to a function pointer).  Also generate the
   31663             : static member whose address is to be returned by the conversion function.
   31664             : In Microsoft mode, generate such pairs of functions for each applicable
   31665             : calling convention type.
   31666             : A definition for these functions is not generated here, but the operator itself
   31667             : will be defined (by define_lambda_conversion_function) once the closure type is
   31668             : complete.  (The body of the static member whose address is returned is
   31669             : generated by lowering if needed.)
   31670             : */
   31671             : {
   31672           0 :   if (lambda_has_conversion_function(lambda) &&
   31673           0 :       !is_template_dependent_context()) {
   31674           0 :     a_type_ptr                    class_type = cdsp->class_type;
   31675           0 :     a_class_type_supplement_ptr   ctsp = class_type_supp(class_type);
   31676           0 :     ctsp->has_lambda_conversion_function = TRUE;
   31677           0 :     if (!microsoft_mode) {
   31678           0 :       a_calling_convention  call_conv = 0;
   31679             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || GNU_X86_ATTRIBUTES_ALLOWED
   31680           0 :       call_conv = (a_calling_convention)cc_default;
   31681             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || GNU_X86_ATTRIBUTES_ALLOWED */
   31682           0 :       generate_lambda_conversion_function(lambda, cdsp, func_info, call_conv);
   31683             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || GNU_X86_ATTRIBUTES_ALLOWED
   31684             :     } else {
   31685             :       /* In Microsoft mode, a special function pair must be created for each
   31686             :          appropriate calling convention.  In C++/CLI mode, that includes
   31687             :          the __clrcall convention.  When targeting x86-64 in Microsoft modes
   31688             :          only __vectorcall (and, in C++/CLI mode, __clrcall) remain (in
   31689             :          addition to the default calling convention). */
   31690             :       /* Define an array with the needed calling conventions: The array
   31691             :          includes an extra slot to be filled in C++/CLI mode. */
   31692             :       a_calling_convention  acc[] = { (a_calling_convention)cc_vectorcall,
   31693             :                                       (a_calling_convention)cc_cdecl,
   31694             :                                       (a_calling_convention)cc_fastcall,
   31695             :                                       (a_calling_convention)cc_stdcall,
   31696             :                                       (a_calling_convention)cc_last };

   31699             :         n_conventions = 2;
   31700             :         acc[1] = (a_calling_convention)cc_default;
   31701             :       }  /* if */
   31702             :       if (cppcli_enabled) {
   31703             :         acc[n_conventions++] = (a_calling_convention)cc_clrcall;
   31704             :       }  /* if */
   31705             :       for (k = 0; k < n_conventions; ++k) {
   31706             :         generate_lambda_conversion_function(lambda, cdsp, func_info, acc[k]);
   31707             :       }  /* for */
   31708             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || GNU_X86_ATTRIBUTES_ALLOWED */
   31709             :     }  /* if */
   31710             :   }  /* if */
   31711           0 : }  /* generate_lambda_conversion_functions_if_needed */
   31712             : 
   31713             : 
   31714           0 : static void define_lambda_conversion_functions_if_needed(a_lambda_ptr  lambda)
   31715             : /*
   31716             : Create bodies for the conversion functions (if any) generated by a prior call
   31717             : to generate_lambda_conversion_functions_if_needed.
   31718             : */
   31719             : {
   31720           0 :   if (lambda_has_conversion_function(lambda)) {
   31721           0 :     a_routine_ptr  rp = class_type_supp(lambda->closure_class)->assoc_scope
   31722             :                                                               ->routines;
   31723           0 :     for (; rp != NULL; rp = rp->next) {
   31724           0 :       if (special_kind_is(rp, sfk_conversion)) {
